description: The program that can originate authoritative responses for a given target resource. c.f. <link=proxy server>proxy</link>, <link=gateway server>gateway</link>, or <link=tunnel server>tunnel</link>

A message-forwarding agent that is selected by the <link=client>client</link>, usually via local configuration rules, to receive requests for some type(s) of absolute URI and attempt to satisfy those requests via translation through the HTTP interface. c.f. <link=origin server>origin</link>, <link=gateway server>gateway</link>, or <link=tunnel server>tunnel</link>

An <link=intermediary>intermediary</link> that acts as an <link=origin server>origin server</link> for the outbound connection but translates received requests and forwards them inbound to another <link=web server>server</link> or servers. c.f. <link=proxy server>proxy</link>, <link=origin server>origin</link>, or <link=tunnel server>tunnel</link>

An <link=intermediary>intermediary</link> that acts as a blind relay between two connections without changing the messages.  Once active, a tunnel is not considered a party to the HTTP communication, though the tunnel might have been initiated by an HTTP request. c.f. <link=proxy server>proxy</link>, <link=gateway server>gateway</link>, or <link=origin server>origin</link>

HTTP enables the use of intermediaries to satisfy requests through a chain of connections.  There are three common forms of HTTP intermediary: proxy, gateway, and tunnel. In some cases, a single intermediary might act as an origin server, proxy, gateway, or tunnel, switching behavior based on the nature of each request.
A program that establishes a connection to a <link=web server>server</link> for the purpose of sending one or more HTTP requests. Also known as a User-Agent.
See: <link=client>Client</link>
The purpose of a collection resource is to model collection-like objects (e.g., file system directories) within a server's namespace.
The Uniform Resource Identifier of the resource being requested in a given transaction.

An HTTP cache is a local store of response messages and the subsystem that controls storage, retrieval, and deletion of messages in it. A cache stores cacheable responses in order to reduce the response time and network bandwidth consumption on future, equivalent requests. Any <link=client>client</link> or <link=web server>server</link> <link=MAY>MAY</link> employ a cache, though a cache cannot be used by a <link=web server>server</link> that is acting as a tunnel.

Request methods can be defined as "cacheable" to indicate that responses to them are allowed to be stored for future reuse; for specific requirements see <link=RFC7234>RFC7234</link>.  In general, <link=safe>safe methods</link> that do not depend on a current or authoritative response are defined as cacheable; this specification defines <link=GET>GET</link>, <link=HEAD>HEAD</link>, and <link=POST>POST</link> as cacheable, although the overwhelming majority of cache implementations only support GET and HEAD.

A "representation" is information that is intended to reflect a past, current, or desired state of a given resource, in a format that can be readily communicated via the protocol, and that consists of a set of representation metadata and a potentially unbounded stream of representation data.

A <link=request method>request method</link> is considered idempotent if the intended effect on the <link=web server>server</link> of multiple identical requests with that method is the same as the effect for a single such request. Of the request methods defined by the HTTP/1.1 specification, <link=PUT>PUT</link>, <link=DELETE>DELETE</link>, and <link=safe>safe</link> request methods are idempotent.

<link=Request method>Request methods</link> are considered "safe" if their defined semantics are essentially read-only; i.e., the <link=client>client</link> does not request, and does not expect, any state change on the <link=origin server>origin server</link> as a result of applying a safe method to a target resource.  Likewise, reasonable use of a safe method is not expected to cause any harm, loss of property, or unusual burden on the origin server. All safe methods are also <link=idempotent>idempotent</link>, however not all idempotent methods are safe (e.g. <link=DELETE>DELETE</link>).
A program that accepts connections in order to service HTTP requests by sending HTTP responses.
Indicates an absolute requirement of the specification.
Indicates an absolute prohibition of the specification.
Indicates a suggested but non-mandatory requirement of the specification.
Indicates a suggested but non-mandatory prohibition of the specification.

The primary source of request semantics; it indicates the purpose for which the <link=client>client</link> has made this request and what is expected by the client as a successful result. Common methods include <link=GET>GET</link>, <link=POST>POST</link>, <link=HEAD>HEAD</link>, <link=TRACE>TRACE</link>, and <link=PUT>PUT</link>. See also: <link=Idempotent>Idempotency</link> and <link=Safe>Safety</link>.
